stem: During follow-up for chronic cubital tunnel syndrome, a patient is asked to grasp a sheet of paper between the thumb and index finger. The thumb flexes at the interphalangeal joint to maintain grip. Which muscle weakness best explains this finding?
rationale_correct: Froment sign indicates weakness of the ulnar-innervated adductor pollicis, forcing compensatory flexion by the median-innervated flexor pollicis longus.

rationale_distractors.B: Flexor pollicis longus flexes the thumb IP joint and is median innervated; it overacts rather than weakens.
rationale_distractors.C: Abductor pollicis brevis is median innervated and affects thumb abduction, not adduction grip strength.
rationale_distractors.D: Extensor pollicis longus extends the thumb; dysfunction would prevent extension, not cause Froment sign.
rationale_distractors.E: Opponens pollicis controls thumb opposition and is median innervated.
